title: Exclusive: DMP Sharks study sheds light on why women's rugby is different to men's
text:
With a quartet of tries in five appearances for Bristol Bears this season, Sarah Bern oozes all the qualities of a bulldozing centre.

She was in fact playing the position just four years ago. While Bern’s successful transition is the most high-profile in the women’s game, it is not unique.

England Sevens bronze Commonwealth medallist Vicky Fleetwood returned to the XV’s format in January not as a pacy winger for Saracens, but as a flanker.

Kat Hobson graduated from full-back to back-rower when she switched to Loughborough at the start of the season, but it is at her former club, DMP Sharks, where this player position phenomenon has been identified as a USP for women’s rugby.

Dr Eddie Bradley, a sports scientist at the University of Sunderland, has spent the past three seasons monitoring players’ training and performance at DMP Sharks using global positioning system (GPS) sensors. He collated data from players across 129 Tyrrells Premier 15s matches, analysing their maximum speed, player loads and the total distance covered on a pitch.
